title: It happened as I said: Communication effects in eyewitness event memory
abstractText:
When describing a perceived event to others, a communicator will tailor the message to the audience. The project examines how a message which is ‘tuned’ to the audience can change or bias the way in which the original event is remembered and evaluated by the communicator.

The project focuses on how eyewitnesses produce their own memory biases during the process of communication with others. A key factor to be varied is ‘shared reality,’ which captures how communicators experience the communication with the person they are tuning to (eg, whether they feel they achieve a joint view with their audience). The likelihood of shared reality creation (high vs. low uncertainty about the event; shared-reality vs. instrumental goals for audience tuning; positive vs. negative audience feedback; appropriate vs. inappropriate audience) will be manipulated in a series of studies.

Standard memory measures and source-memory tests will determine whether eyewitnesses exhibiting a greater memory bias are less likely to discriminate correctly between information from the witnessed event and communicated information.
